HumanImpact.li: By conducting massive surveillance operations over hundreds of millions of Americans and millions of others overseas and insisting that it has the right to do so whenever it feels American interests may be involved, the United States Government has violated the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution. The willingness of Congress, the Executive Branch, and even the Courts to go along with this program bodes ill for the future of our civil liberties. While it likely can be truthfully said that this surveillance program is not currently being abused to do things like shut down political opposition, the US Government has a history of doing such things in the past (COINTELPRO, Alien and Sedition Acts, Japanese Internment, etc.), and blindly trusting that such immense power would never be abused or wielded against the interests of the American people will not end well.

EconomicImpact.li: As a result of the United States Government's decision to implement an extensive surveillance program not only on its own citizens, but also on foreign allies, there has been significant damage to the USA's relations with other countries. As a result, relations between them have become strained, resulting in countries becoming less willing to encourage economic interactions with America.

In addition, fear that the US government may be spying on them has led many European businesses and entities associated with European governments to drop or consider dropping American telecommunications service providers such as Verizon and ATT.

WaysToHelp.li: Restore The Fourth
Donate To Fight For The Future
Donate To Electronic Frontier Foundation
Contact Your Representative Through Fight For The Future
Contact Your Representative Through Electronic Frontier Foundation

Images.li: NSA Supercomputers Storing and Mining Massive Quantities of Data
NSA Headquarters
Director of Intelligence for the United States of America James Clapper
Edward Snowden The man who leaked the details of the NSA's surveillance program being interviewed in Hong Kong
The Government's Always Listening...

Common.Summary: The NSA has, ever since September 11, 2001, been steadily expanding its reach and in doing so has quickly crossed the boundaries of what is legal. Driven by a need to know essentially everything, the NSA has begun warrantlessly wiretapping American citizens and collecting massive quantities of metadata about hundreds of millions of Americans and foreigners. Claiming that they are allowed this power because it "might be related to an investigation" the NSA has attempted to claim that their methods are fully legal and allowed by American Law, but this claim is clearly in violation of our constitutional rights. More importantly, it puts the NSA, and by proxy the US government, in a position of astonishing power, power that they have shown the capability of abusing in the past.

HumanImpact.li: Colony collapse disorder can catastrophically reduce global food supply because it’s believed that one third of human nutrition is due to bee pollination.

EconomicImpact.li: Shortages of bees in the US have increased the cost to farmers of renting them for pollination services by up to 20%

ResourcesNeeded.li: Government colaboration to change current laws about pesticides

WaysToHelp.li: Use of alternative pollinators like leafcutter, alkali bees, or bumblebees
Hand Pollination which is labor intensive, time consuming, and costly.
Prairie restoration
Establishment of wildlife preserves
encouragement of diverse wildlife landscaping rather than monoculture lawns

HumanImpact.li: These wildfires burned 2,862 homes, caused six fatalities, including two firefighters, and injuring 62 other people.

EconomicImpact.li: They also burned down over 2,700 other structures, causing a total of $510.927 million in damages.1 FEMA has reimbursed the state of Texas $48 million for the fire suppression costs during the wildfires.

WaysToHelp.li: Texas Wildfire Relief
Donate To Help The Children: Project Help Texas

Smoke rises from wildfire near Possum Kingdom, Texas

Common.Summary: Spurred on by the currently ongoing 2011 Southern US Drought, the 2011 Texas Wildfires, beginning on November 15, 2013 and ending on October 31, 2011, were some of the worst the state of Texas has ever seen. It included what is generally acknowledged to be the most catastrophic wildfire in Texas history - the Bastrop County Complex Fire which destroyed over 1600 homes and burned over 34,000 acres of land, killing two people. Declaring a State of Disaster on December 21, 2010, Texas Governor Rick Perry requested President Obama to send federal aid to help with the wildfires.

Brazilian citizens feel too much money is being spent on the 2015 World Cup

Common.Summary: The 2013 Brazilian protests started as upset citizens protesting the increase of fares of public transportation methods. Lately the protests have evolved into demanding a better oversite of government workers, better public transportation with lesser cost, and controversy over hosting the 2015 World Cup.

HumanImpact.li: The Mexican drug war is not a conventional war, but with more than 60,000 killed in Mexico in the last several years it has a high enough death toll to be one.
At least 106 US residents killed by April 2011.
An additional 230,000 people have been displaced, half internally and half in US.

The US State Department considers Mexico to be a Tier 2 country for human trafficking. While not entirely responsible for the situation, drug cartels exacerbate it, both by directly by subjecting captives to forced labor and prostitution and through the general atmosphere of lawlessness. Central Americans passing through Mexico on their way to the United States make up a significant portion of the human trafficking victims.

EconomicImpact.li: Although the drug trade injects billions of dollars into the Mexican economy each year and employs many people, it is generally considered to be detrimental to the Mexican economy. Mexico's economy has enjoyed strong growth during the conflict, but a 1% reduction to economic growth each year and total economic losses of $4.3 billion dollars per year due to violence, lost investment, and drug use are attributed to it.

ResourcesNeeded.li: Decreased drug demand or increased supply.

An military/law enforcement solution is possible but very difficult. It could be attempted with a heavy police or military presence throughout Mexico, an elimination of drug supply from South America, or an elimination of the illegal drug market in the United States. A combination of all three would be effective but each would be difficult to achieve.

WaysToHelp.li: Legalize drugs. Legalizing marijuana in California could reduce drug trafficking revenues by 20%.
Abstain from drugs, reducing the demand for drug and as a consequence, the price of drugs, which is the incentive for the drug war.
Use drugs from local sources. Encouraging local drug production leads to increased drug supply reduces, which reduces the price.

Citations.li: "Q&A: Mexico's drug-related violence". BBC News: Latin America and Caribbean. Updated: 16 July, 2013. Visited: 3 August, 2013.
"Mexican Drug War". Wikipedia. Updated: 3 August, 2013. Visited: 3 August, 2013.

The Indian Airforce has flown hundreds of sorties every day to airdrop food and fuel for trapped villages.

HumanImpact.li: Anger towards the corruption in the Egyptian political system influenced millions of protesters to join plaza marches and other demonstrations against the government.
Many protests were organized using social media, demonstrating the powerful new influence of technology over politics and human action.
The movement united Egytian citizens over a spectrum of socio-economic and religious foundations.
Eight hundred forty-six people were killed and around six thousand have been injured participating in demonstrations against Egypt's police and military.

EconomicImpact.li: As the government is restructured in Egypt, the economic situation of people will change based our their dependency on the corrupt system as a source of wealth.
It is possible that the gap in leadership will be taken advantage of and a party with a different form of corruption will refactor the system completely.
If Egypt adopts a better set of leaders, it may positively influence its trade with Western countries.
Importers of Egypts oil will see prices of gasoline affected by the turnover of Egypts political leaders.

HumanImpact.li: The United Nations' FAO states that by 2025, 1.9 billion people will be living in countries or regions with absolute water scarcity, and two-thirds of the world population could be under stress conditions.

EconomicImpact.li: Several solutions to the problem are expensive.
Construciton and maintenance of wastewater treatment plants is highly capital intensive and many regions don't have access to such technology.
Reducing groundwater overdrafting reduces crop yield, negatively impacting farmers and world's populations food needs.

ResourcesNeeded.li: Construction of wastewater treatment plants to produce more potable water, but there are issues to this.
Reducing groundwater overdrafting, but there are issues to this
Developing countries need to improve primary wastewater treatment. They should also develop more secure septic systems, such as more widespread adoption of septic tanks.

WaysToHelp.li: Non-profit organization aimed at bringing clean, safe drinking water to people in developing countrie
The Water Project: Bring Clean Water to Africa
Help people gain access to safe water and sanitation.

HumanImpact.li: Natural systems account for about half of GDP of poor.
Almost 3 billion people rely on wood for fuel and timber.

ResourcesNeeded.li: Land-efficient agriculture. Modern technology and plants offer greater yields than subsistence agriculture and the raising of livestock. 48% of deforestation is due to subsistence and 32% due to commercial agriculture.

WaysToHelp.li: Eat plant products. Livestock is much more land-intensive.
Limit paper use.
Use fuels besides wood.

Common.Summary: As the human race continues to expand both in population and, as a result, in space occupied, the need for land grows, which has led to a rapid decrease in the size of our world's forests. If this keeps up, it is only a short matter of time before the forests are all but gone

HumanImpact.li: Nuclear weapons can kill hundreds of thousands of people at a time.
Nuclear power has the potential to destroy entire cities and hundreds of years of human development in an instant.

Radiation lingers in an environment for an unknown amount of time after a nuclear blast, meaning that a location can be permanently altered. This may cause an increase in cancer rates within that environment.

EconomicImpact.li: Nuclear weapons represent power (persuasive power?) and are a direct demonstration of a country's wealth in technology and science.
The components involved with nuclear power are so reactive as to be intolerable to human and environmental systems. Thus, nuclear energy is criticized as being a profit-for-person trade off.

Russian President Vladimir Putin. He recently agreed to grant Snowden political asylum for 1 year.
Edward Snowden being interviewed in Hong Kong after leaking details of NSA's surveillance program to the press

Common.Summary: Edward Snowden is a whistleblower who revealed the NSA's PRISM surveillance program. Throughout his life, he has had a history of working in defense of the US government, first as a Special Forces recruit, then as an NSA security guard, and finally as a private contractor working for Booz Allen Hamilton inside the NSA at the Kunia Regional SIGINT Operations Center in Hawaii. He grew increasingly unsettled as he learned just how far the US government was going with its surveillance program and believed that the decision of how far the US government was allowed to go lay with the American people and not with the NSA or the executive branch. In an attempt to correct the situation, he released information about the NSA's PRISM surveillance program to The Guardian's Glenn Greenwald and fled the US to first Hong Kong and later Russia. Currently, he is trapped in Moscow Airport, attempting to gain political asylum and safe transport to another country.

Citations.li: "Rafael Correa". Wikipedia. Updated: 15 July, 2013. Visited: 23 July, 2013.

Images.li: Ecuadorian President Rafael Correa
Rafael Correa anxiously awaiting the results of a controversial referendum to ban cockfighting

Common.Summary: Rafael Correa is the president of the Republic of Ecuador. He is also the former president of the Union of South American Nations. Elected in 2006, he used his power as president of Ecuador to declare Ecuador's national debt illegitimate and successfully fought in international courts to have the debt reduced by 60%. He is currently famous, however, for offering to provide asylum to Edward Snowden, the whistleblower who leaked information about the American government's vast surveillance program known as PRISM and for protecting Wikileaks founder Julian Assange by allowing him to remain within the Ecuadorian embassy in the United Kingdom.

Common.Summary: Born in Paint Creek, Texas on March 4, 1950, Rick Perry is currently the Governor of the state of Texas. He is a staunchly conservative politician who is famous for attempting to name 3 federal agencies he intended to end if he won the 2012 Presidential Election but failing to be able to name the third. He is also famous for holding 3 days of prayer in an attempt to end the Texas Wildfire crisis in 2011. Eventually, Texas firefighters were able to successfully put out the flames as the wildfire season drew to a close. Perry requested federal aid, and in response, FEMA reimbursed the state of Texas $48 million for fire suppression costs.

Crowds rallying for the deposing of Egyptian President Mohamed Morsi

Common.Summary: Born on August 8, 1951, Mohamed Morsi was elected as President of Egypt and assumed office on April 30, 2011. However, many Egyptian citizens were unhappy with his heavy-handed approach to governance and with his strong leaning towards incorporating religion into law. They were especially displeased with his decision to significantly expand his presidential powers and remove judicial review of his decrees soon after being elected into office. As a result, he was deposed on July 3, 2013.

Common.Summary: The Union of Concerned Scientists is an organization founded in 1969 by the faculty and students of MIT in Cambridge, Massachusetts. The goal of this nonprofit group is to advocate for an increased focus on the sciences, and positive action to curb global warming, deforestation, militarization, and reliance on oil

History.li: The National Security Agency (NSA) was originally known as Armed Forces Security Agency (AFSA), which was created on May 20, 1949. AFSA, however, failed to achieve its goal of a centralized intelligence community due to its inability to coordinate properly with civilian agencies with similar goals, such as the FBI.

In light of this failure, the agency was overhauled, strengthened, and rebranded as the NSA in 1952. It has a storied history of protecting the United States from its enemies, providing it with the intelligence needed to capture and remove the threat of enemy spies within its borders while also providing the government with insight into what the USA's enemies are thinking and planning.

Spurred by the recent emergence of terrorism as a significant threat to national security on September 11, 2011, however, the NSA has steadily grown its intelligence gathering capabilities to the point where it has begun ignoring the Constitution and American law by wiretapping American citizens without first obtaining a warrant and by obtaining massive amounts of metadata about what American citizens are doing over the internet.

In order to manage these expanded operations, the NSA has begun building a new facility in Utah said to be capable of storing data at the level of yottabytes (1 yottabyte = 1 trillion terabytes) of data.

The Mugamma: The Center of Egypt's Sprawling Bureaucracy

Videos.li: Egypt's anti-government protesters celebrate army's ultimatum
Egypt swears in new interim government

Common.Summary: Right now Egypt's governmental structure is highly unstable and is largely influenced by the military and corrupt politicians.

Organization.Name: International Union for Conservation of Nature

History.li: Founded in 1948.
Over 1,000 staff members, 1,200 member organizations, and 11,000 volunteer scientists and experts.

Citations.li: "International Union for Conservation of Nature". Wikipedia. Updated: 29 July, 2013. Visited: 3 August, 2013.

ExternalLinks.li: Wikipedia: International Union for Conservation of Nature

Images.li: IUCN's Logo

Videos.li: International Union for Conservation of Nature>

Common.Summary: The International Union for Conservation of Nature is an organization whose primary purpose is to find pragmatic solutions to the most pressing environmental and developmental challenges that our world faces

History.li: Founded in 1989, the Sinaloa Cartel has become the most powerful cartel in the last few years. It's success has come in part from infiltrating and bribing Mexican officals and being less confrontational than other cartels. While minimizing direct conflict with the Mexican government, the Sinaloa Cartel is at war with rival cartels, including Los Zetas, and is a big part of the Mexican drug violence.
Its leader is Joaquin Guzman Loera, Mexico's most wanted man.
In addition to weed and cocaine, the Sinaloas control 80% of the US meth trade.

Citations.li: "Sinaloa Cartel". Wikipedia. Updated: 1 August, 2013. Visited: 3 August, 2013.

li.text: This is the alt element of the image.
This is the alt element of the image.

Common.Summary: Sinaloa Cartel is the premiere drug cartel in Mexico

History.li: Founded in 1999

Citations.li: "Los Zetas". Wikipedia. Updated: 1 August, 2013. Visited: 3 August, 2013.

Common.Summary: One of the largest two Mexican drug cartels, Los Zetas dominate Northeastern Mexico bordering of Texas. Whereas the Sinaloa cartel favors bribery and diplomacy, Los Zetas tend toward confronation and brutality, including extortions, beheadings, and mass killings.

History.li: Involved in violent conflict with drug cartels since a government crackdown in 2006. Over 1000 Mexican police and prosecutors have been killed.

Citations.li: "Federal Government of Mexico". Wikipedia. Updated: 18 May, 2013. Visited: 3 August, 2013.

Common.Summary: The Mexican government is the institution that runs the country of Mexico. Ever since 2006, they have been locked in a violent struggle against the drug cartels that have gained power in the country. The result has been a bloody conflict leaving tens of thousands dead. Part of the problem is that the government has become so corrupt that officials are often caught aiding the cartels.

History.li: Founded in 2005.

Citations.li: Galpin, Richard. "Violence Feared over Moscow Gay March." BBC News. BBC, 14 May 2009. Web. 10 July 2013..
"Nikolai Alexeyev Arrested In Attempted Moscow Gay Pride Parade." On Top Magazine. N.p., 27 May 2012. Web. 10 July 2013

Common.Summary: Founded in 2005, LGBT Human Rights Project GayRussia.Ru (Gayrussia.ru) is an LGBT Advocate organization in Russia.

History.li: Current constitution which was passed in 1988 is very democratic
There are two political parties which are internationalist liberals and state nationalists
President is both Head of State and Head of Government
Central government compose of executive, judicial, and legislative branches

Citations.li: Politics of Brazil: 20 June, 2013. Visited: 11 July, 2013.

Images.li: Brazilian Government

Common.Summary: The governing body of the country of the state of Brazil, Presidential Representative Democratic Republic.

History.li: Water.org is an American nonprofit developmental aid organization resulting from the merger between H2O Africa, co-founded by Matt Damon, and WaterPartners, co-founded by Gary White in July 2009.

Citations.li: West, Larry. "World Water Day: A Billion People Worldwide Lack Safe Drinking Water." About.com Environmental Issues. N.p., n.d. Web. 11 July 2013.
Spector, Mike. "Coalition Pledges $400 Million For Clean Water, Sanitation." The Wall Street Journal. N.p., n.d. Web. 11 July 2013.

ExternalLinks.li: "World Water Day: A Billion People Worldwide Lack Safe Drinking Water."
"Coalition Pledges $400 Million For Clean Water, Sanitation.

Common.Summary: A nonprofit developmental aide organization whose goal is to provide aid to regions of developing countries that do not have access to safe drinking water and sanitation.
